awd_abstract_narration:
Icebergs influence climate by controlling how freshwater from ice sheets is distributed into the ocean, where roughly half of ice sheet mass loss is attributed to iceberg calving in the current climate. The freshwater deposited by icebergs as they drift and melt can affect ocean circulation, sea-ice formation, and biological primary productivity. Furthermore, calving of icebergs from ice shelves, the floating extensions of ice sheets, can influence ice sheet evolution and sea-level rise by reducing the resistive stresses provided by ice shelves on the seaward flow of upstream grounded ice. The majority of mass calved from ice shelves occurs in the form of tabular icebergs, which are typically hundreds of meters thick and on the order of tens to hundreds of kilometers in length and width. Tabular calving occurs when full-thickness ice shelf fractures known as rifts propagate to the edges of the ice shelf. These calving events are infrequent, often with decades between events on an individual ice shelf. Changes in tabular calving behavior, i.e., the size and frequency of calving events, can strongly influence climate and ice sheet evolution. However, tabular calving behavior, and how it responds to changes in climate, is neither well understood nor accurately represented in climate models.

In this project, a tabular calving parameterization for climate models will be developed. The parameterization will be derived according to data generated from a series of realistic and idealized century-scale tabular calving simulations, which will be performed with a novel ice flow and damage framework that can be applied at the scale of individual ice sheet-ice shelf systems: the CD-MPM-SSA (Continuum Damage Material Point Method for Shelfy-Stream Approximation). During these simulations, the geometry of the ice shelf, mechanical/rheological properties of the ice, and climate forcings such as ocean temperature will be varied to determine the rifting and calving response. The calving parameterization derived from these experiments will be implemented in a Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL) climate model, where it will be coupled with a bonded-particle iceberg model. Then, experiments will be run to study the feedback between changes in iceberg calving behavior and climate. Success of this project will improve our understanding and representation of the ice mass budget, ice sheet evolution, and ocean freshwater fluxes, and will improve projections of climate change and sea-level rise.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rifts are full-thickness fractures in ice shelves, the floating extensions of ice sheets. They can cause large "tabular" icebergs to break off from ice shelves in a process known as calving. These icebergs drift away and deposit freshwater into the ocean as they melt, which can affect ocean circulation and sea-ice formation.

The overarching goal that motivated this project was to represent tabular calving within Earth system models. We developed a novel ice-shelf flow and damage modeling framework that can simulate rifting, and which accounts for several ice properties and climate-related processes that control rifting. For example, our framework accounts for the backpressure on rift-flank walls from contact between opposing flanks and from floating ice melange that may exist between the flanks. This melange is typically composed of small icebergs, sea-ice, snow, and marine ice that freezes onto its base. In our framework, the strength of the melange can vary, where stronger (i.e. mechanically-coherent) melange can act to "glue" rift flanks together.

We applied our modeling framework within a study where we investigated how rift-flank contact and melange properties influence the rift path, and thus, the size of tabular icebergs. The size of an iceberg is a major control on where it drifts and deposits meltwater into the ocean. We focused on simulating the observed rift propagation that led to the calving of iceberg A68 from Larsen C ice shelf in 2017 (Fig 1). Through a series of simulations, we demonstrated that substantial rift-flank contact or weak melange fill resulted in shorter rift paths and smaller iceberg calving events than observed; however, assigning mechanically-coherent melange or no melange at all yielded rift paths and larger icebergs consistent with observations (Fig 2). Simulations that resulted in smaller bergs were associated with greater rift-widening rates than the simulations that resulted in larger bergs.

Another contribution of this study was a novel inverse modeling procedure that we developed to initialize damage and ice stiffness fields that minimize mismatch between observed and modeled velocity. This procedure optimizes a damage field with sharp spatial gradients consistent with fracture, and a smoother ice stiffness field consistent with more gradual spatial changes in ice temperature and fabric.

We presented this research at two conferences and submitted a manuscript for publication. We also mentored an undergraduate researcher as part of the Cooperative Institute for Modeling the Earth System Research Intern Program. The intern used machine learning to track the rift that led to iceberg A68 in satellite imagery. Upon terminating the postdoctoral fellowship, the PI took a position at the NOAA Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory.
